commit_message:
Temporarily make lbaasv2-minimal job non-voting, due to breakage

This patch makes the lbaasv2-minimal job non-voting
temporarily. This patch also removes the lbaasv2-
minimal job from the neutron-lbaas and octavia gate
pipelines.

Change-Id: I9414f7addb38ea4dceb7ff99e5793685d69370df

subject: Revert "Support `truncated` flag returned by keystone"
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-13 21:36:13.000000000', 'files': ['keystoneclient/base.py', 'keystoneclient/tests/unit/v3/utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient/commit/d20b300589863bcf165945beb129ebcc3621a14f', 'message': 'Revert "Support `truncated` flag returned by keystone"

This reverts commit c28d40814962b3a8ccb81e5e7d7f832c8f0a3c9a.

This is causing stable keystone to fail. keystone has tests
that verify that the returned value of the list
operation == [], which fails since the return value is now
an object and not a list.

Change-Id: Ieb143574271b991d3e19e864497073fbedf46bcb
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Support `truncated` flag returned by keystone"

This reverts commit c28d40814962b3a8ccb81e5e7d7f832c8f0a3c9a.

This is causing stable keystone to fail. keystone has tests
that verify that the returned value of the list
operation == [], which fails since the return value is now
an object and not a list.

Change-Id: Ieb143574271b991d3e19e864497073fbedf46bcb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/87/267187/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def encode(self, entity): if isinstance(entity, dict): return {self.key: entity} if isinstance(entity, list): return {self.collection_key: entity} def test_list(self, ref_list=None, expected_path=None, expected_query=None, **filter_kwargs): json=self.encode(ref_list))
deleted_lines: def encode(self, entity, truncated=None): encoded = {} if truncated is not None: encoded['truncated'] = truncated if isinstance(entity, dict): encoded[self.key] = entity return encoded if isinstance(entity, list): encoded[self.collection_key] = entity return encoded def _test_list(self, ref_list=None, expected_path=None, expected_query=None, truncated=None, **filter_kwargs): # We want to catch all cases: when `truncated` is not returned by the # server, when it's False and when it's True. # Attribute `truncated` of the returned list-like object should exist # in all these cases. It should be False if the server returned a list # without the flag. expected_truncated = False if truncated: expected_truncated = truncated json=self.encode(ref_list, truncated=truncated)) self.assertEqual(expected_truncated, returned_list.truncated) def test_list(self, ref_list=None, expected_path=None, expected_query=None, **filter_kwargs): # test simple list, without any truncation self._test_list(ref_list, expected_path, expected_query, **filter_kwargs) # test when a server returned a list with truncated=False self._test_list(ref_list, expected_path, expected_query, truncated=False, **filter_kwargs) # test when a server returned a list with truncated=True self._test_list(ref_list, expected_path, expected_query, truncated=True, **filter_kwargs)

commit_message:
Adding link for SELinux policies

This patch adds a link to the latest SELinux policies available for OpenStack
services. At the moment, I'm unable to find any AppArmor profiles for
securing OpenStack services, but I included a mention of OpenStack-Ansible's
method of applying AppArmor profiles to containers that run OpenStack
services.

Closes-bug: 1459820

Change-Id: Id44e49c4ab93991921d9ef2a71077a05589ab6c6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-doc refs/changes/67/266567/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Specific SELinux policies are available for many OpenStack services. Many of these appear in Fedora's `selinux-policy <https://github.com/fedora-selinux/selinux-policy>`__ repository. The `rawhide-contrib <https://github.com/fedora-selinux/selinux-policy/tree/rawhide-contrib>`__ branch has files that end in ``.te``, such as ``cinder.te``, that can be used on systems running SELinux. AppArmor profiles for OpenStack services don't currently exist, but the OpenStack-Ansible project handles this by `applying AppArmor profiles <http://docs.openstack.org/developer/openstack-ansible/install-guide/overview-security.html#apparmor>`__ to each container that runs an OpenStack service.

commit_message:
Use assertTrue/False instead of assertEqual(T/F)

The usage of assertEqual(True/False, ***) should be changed
to a meaningful format of assertTrue/False(***).

Change-Id: Ia51e577fd89a208e9574fea987652522cadffdc4
Closes-Bug:#1512207

commit_message:
Use pymysql database driver for OpenStack DBs

PyMySQL is a new driver introduced in Liberty.
This patch change the MySQL url to use mysql+pymysql like recommanded.

Change-Id: I28e14acacba865241a0cc388a879a003181a85f3
Depends-On: I7604cca9e2d7bf0b93c820adec5f937f72b64fa8
Closes-Bug: #1499298

commit_message:
Refactor network endpoint enablement checking

Move the network endpoint enablement checking from the 'server create'
command to the common client manager. This allows future network
commands to use either nova or neutron networking based on the cloud
environment.

This patch set also includes related unit test enhancements to the
common client manager to trigger authentication on the tests.

Change-Id: Ia37e81d4fb05a1e2fceb3e5d367bda769ab8e64b
Related-Bug: #1519511
Related-to: blueprint neutron-client

Docs: overview cleanup

Cleaning up the About page and merging in Ansible/LXC overviews since
those technologies are talked about in the About page anyway.

Change-Id: I571ef104be977b87bf484e64b855128318a287b4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/03/265303/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: `Home <index.html>`_ OpenStack-Ansible Installation Guide Ansible ------- OpenStack-Ansible Deployment uses a combination of Ansible and Linux Containers (LXC) to install and manage OpenStack. Ansible provides an automation platform to simplify system and application deployment. Ansible manages systems using Secure Shell (SSH) instead of unique protocols that require remote daemons or agents. Ansible uses *playbooks* written in the YAML language for orchestration. For more information, see `Ansible - Intro to Playbooks <http://docs.ansible.com/playbooks_intro.html>`_. In this guide, we refer to the host running Ansible playbooks as the *deployment host* and the hosts on which Ansible installs OSA as the *target hosts*. A recommended minimal layout for deployments involves five target hosts in total: three infrastructure hosts, one compute host, and one logging host. All hosts require three network interfaces. More information on setting up target hosts can be found in `the section called "Host layout" <overview-hostlayout.html>`_. For more information on physical, logical, and virtual network interfaces within hosts see `the section called "Host networking" <overview-hostnetworking.html>`_. -------------- .. include:: navigation.txt

commit_message:
Revert "Change default endpoint for Keystone v3 to public"

This reverts commit d3b11d674d6539a0a09e0c432983ebf172e8ad79.

This is causing auth_token middleware tests to fail. The error is
like:

 EndpointNotFound: public endpoint for identity service in east
 region not found

So this is going to potentially affect customers.

Change-Id: I5ad917e48c9b140709dd3bf95e89c07ea58d6a66

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-13 20:55:40.000000000', 'files': ['astara/db/sqlalchemy/alembic/versions/4f695b725637_initial_migration.py', 'devstack/plugin.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/astara/commit/da8d8cd9fc04b4d0ac468cf4789175693a6cf3d2', 'message': 'gate fixer: Fix devstack auth issue and new PEP8 violation

Squashes two commits needed to unblock the gate:

devstack: prevent auth params set in env. polluting client calls

The switch to keystone v3 has introduces issues when other devstack
components set tenant or project name in environment, as it overrides

'}]
commit_message:
gate fixer: Fix devstack auth issue and new PEP8 violation

Squashes two commits needed to unblock the gate:

devstack: prevent auth params set in env. polluting client calls

The switch to keystone v3 has introduces issues when other devstack
components set tenant or project name in environment, as it overrides
those set by us in our plugin script.  This ensures that doesnt happen.
It also updates usage of upload_image to avoid issuing a token (no longer
needed) and uses openstack client to create the nova flavor using clouds.yaml.

Fix E402 pep8 violation

Change-Id: Icfd0790e0f23bc9daaef6e006e39e3b94e42417e

added_lines: openstack --os-cloud=devstack-admin flavor create astara \ --id $ROUTER_INSTANCE_FLAVOR_ID --ram $ROUTER_INSTANCE_FLAVOR_RAM \ --disk $ROUTER_INSTANCE_FLAVOR_DISK --vcpus $ROUTER_INSTANCE_FLAVOR_CPUS # having these set by something else in devstack will override those that we pass on # CLI. unset OS_TENANT_NAME OS_PROJECT_NAME upload_image $astara_dev_image_src
deleted_lines: nova flavor-create astara $ROUTER_INSTANCE_FLAVOR_ID \ $ROUTER_INSTANCE_FLAVOR_RAM $ROUTER_INSTANCE_FLAVOR_DISK \ $ROUTER_INSTANCE_FLAVOR_CPUS env TOKEN=$(openstack token issue -c id -f value) die_if_not_set $LINENO TOKEN "Keystone fail to get token" upload_image $astara_dev_image_src $TOKEN

DO NOT MERGE - stub for oslo messaging work

This imcomplete stub is a placeholder for discussion on the
DseNode class interface.

Change-Id: I49b78c11cc40fbd80a3e70013b42a3553551e126
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/59/210159/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python # coding: utf-8 from oslo_config import cfg import oslo_messaging as messaging import logging import uuid import eventlet eventlet.monkey_patch() logging.basicConfig() log = logging.getLogger() log.addHandler(logging.StreamHandler()) log.setLevel(logging.INFO) CONTROL_TOPIC = 'control' class EVENT_TYPES: topic_publish = 'PUBLISHED_TOPICS' class ControlNotificationHandler(object): def info(self, ctxt, publisher_id, event_type, payload, metadata): log.info('Received topics: %s' % payload) #if publisher_id == 'testing': # log.info('Handled') # return messaging.NotificationResult.HANDLED def warn(self, ctxt, publisher_id, event_type, payload, metadata): log.error('Unexpected WARN notification on control bus') def error(self, ctxt, publisher_id, event_type, payload, metadata): log.error('Unexpected ERROR notification on control bus') class DseNode(object): def __init__(self, node_id): self.node_id = node_id self.driver = 'messaging' self.transport_url = 'rabbit://testing:test@127.0.0.1:5672/' self.transport = messaging.get_transport(cfg.CONF, self.transport_url) targets = [messaging.Target(topic=CONTROL_TOPIC)] # TODO: how to update topic subscription endpoints = [ControlNotificationHandler()] self.server = messaging.get_notification_listener(self.transport, targets, endpoints, allow_requeue=True, executor='eventlet') self.notifier = messaging.Notifier( self.transport, driver=self.driver, publisher_id=self.node_id, topic=CONTROL_TOPIC) def published_topics(self): # TODO: replace this stub with real data return ["%s-topic1" % self.node_id, "%s-topic2" % self.node_id] def message_context(self): return {'node_id': self.node_id} def publish_topics(self): # Publish all of our topics on the control bus log.info('Publishing topics') self.notifier.info(self.message_context(), EVENT_TYPES.topic_publish, self.published_topics()) def subscribe_to_control_bus(self): # XXX broken - we already subscribed in the constructor log.info('Configuring control bus connection') transport = messaging.get_transport(cfg.CONF, self.transport_url) def join_bus(self): log.info('Joining bus') self.subscribe_to_control_bus() self.publish_topics() # Subscribe to the "control" topic # Broadcast request to see if my node ID is already present (if so, exit) # Perform peer discovery # # Publish "I'm here" to control topic (including what topics I export) # Publish again when any peer discovery message is received # Publish (broadcast) peer discovery request to "control" topic # Update local topic registry with all "I'm here" responses (if data is needed by node logic) pass log.info('Joined') #TBD: publish(), rpc() node = DseNode(str(uuid.uuid4())) log.info('Starting up node %s' % node.node_id) eventlet.spawn(node.join_bus) node.server.start() node.server.wait()

commit_message:
Chef-Zero software config hook

Implements a software config hook for using chef-zero, an in-memory,
standalone chef service. Chef-Zero has replaced chef-solo as the
preferred serverless implementation, therfore this patch replaces
the previous chef-solo patch at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/80229/.

Change-Id: Ic93b2e67be0c07e27d26ed2c6677c5a0f1b42e07
Closes-Bug: #1279062
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-templates refs/changes/14/261114/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update gate-check-lint to match Liberty

This patch changes gate-check-commit in Kilo to match the script in
the Liberty branch.

Change-Id: Ib2325a8fa818366dfdb1286d70b050f38532e0cc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/42/267242/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # next, bootstrap Ansible source $(dirname ${0})/bootstrap-ansible.shif [ -f "test-requirements.txt" ]; then pip2 install -r test-requirements.txt || pip install -r test-requirements.txt
deleted_lines: if [ -f "dev-requirements.txt" ]; then pip2 install -r dev-requirements.txt || pip install -r dev-requirements.txt# Run hacking/flake8 check for all python files # Ignores the following rules due to how ansible modules work in general # F403 'from ansible.module_utils.basic import *' used; unable to detect undefined names # H303 No wildcard (*) import. flake8 --ignore=F403,H303 $(grep -rln -e '^#!/usr/bin/env python' -e '^#!/bin/python' -e '^#!/usr/bin/python' * )

subject: Fix neutron migrations with optional providers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-13 16:40:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/49ca92b5f81d4fdfa6d12541ceed830a0e79050d', 'message': '[WIP] Fix neutron migrations with optional providers

The venv creation process would include all python packages into the venv
even if the optional provider was not used. This causes neutron migration
issues and creates unneeded table. To resolve this, the py_pkg lookup
plugin has been modified to ensure no "optional" pip packages are included
in the base venv.

The optional string was added to the "plumgrid_pip_packages" array to ensure
the lookup plugin is no longer indexing those packages for inclusion in the
base venv.

Change-Id: I999ebd52d99f984d7bfa19685fc0fa530c2b32a9
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-01-13 16:51:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/2b0e36453781add764dc05060bd64875a26b24a4', 'message': '[WIP] Fix neutron migrations with optional providers

commit_message:
Fix neutron migrations with optional providers

The venv creation process would include all python packages into the venv
even if the optional provider was not used. This causes neutron migration
issues and creates unneeded table. To resolve this, the py_pkg lookup
plugin has been modified to ensure no "optional" pip packages are included
in the base venv.

The optional string was added to the "plumgrid_pip_packages" array to ensure
the lookup plugin is no longer indexing those packages for inclusion in the
base venv.

Note:
This patch includes a tox.ini configuration change to make it use
test-requirements.txt for the pep8 environment dependencies. This is
essential to allow the lint testing to pass and can be reverted later.

Change-Id: I999ebd52d99f984d7bfa19685fc0fa530c2b32a9
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

deleted_lines: with_items: neutron_plumgrid_pip_packages - neutron_get_venv | failed

commit_message:
Create dse2.DseNode class

DseNodes represent message bus endpoints.  A DseNode establishes
a control bus over the message bus to communicate status with
peer DseNodes.

Each DseNode may expose:
 - Node specific RPC endpoints
 - DataServices

Partially-implements: blueprint dist-cross-process-dse
Change-Id: I505c7489e9fc4972d72688a97c24b7f7c1287950

added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python # Copyright (c) 2015 VMware, Inc. All rights reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # import functools import json import sys import time import uuid import eventlet eventlet.monkey_patch() from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_log import log as logging import oslo_messaging as messaging from congress.common import config LOG = logging.getLogger() _dse_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('node_id', help='Unique ID of this Node on the DSE') ] cfg.CONF.register_opts(_dse_opts, group='dse') # TODO: get messaging url from config cfg.CONF.transport_url = 'rabbit://testing:test@127.0.0.1:5672/' class DataService(object): """Data Service on the DSE. Attributes: service_id: The ID of the service. node_id: The ID of the node the service is running on. published_tables: List of table IDs published by this service. subscribed_tables: List of table IDs this service subscribes to. last_hb_time: Timestamp when last heartbeat received for this service. """ MARSHALL_ATTRS = set(['service_id', 'node_id', 'published_tables', 'subscribed_tables']) def __init__(self, service_id=None, node_id=None, published_tables=None, subscribed_tables=None): self.service_id = service_id self.node_id = node_id self.published_tables = published_tables or [] self.subscribed_tables = subscribed_tables or [] self.last_hb_time = None def __repr__(self): return self.__class__.__name__ + "(%s)" % dict.__repr__(vars(self)) @classmethod def from_json(cls, json_string): return json.loads(json_string, object_hook=cls.from_dict) @classmethod def from_dict(cls, raw_dict): provided_keys = set(raw_dict.keys()) if provided_keys != cls.MARSHALL_ATTRS: missing = cls.MARSHALL_ATTRS - provided_keys malformed = provided_keys - cls.MARSHALL_ATTRS msg = "Cannot construct %s from input:" % cls.__name__ if missing: msg += " Missing keys: %s" % list(missing) if malformed: msg += " Malformed keys: %s" % list(malformed) raise KeyError(msg) ret = DataService() for n in cls.MARSHALL_ATTRS: setattr(ret, n, raw_dict[n]) return ret def to_dict(self): return dict([(k, getattr(self, k)) for k in self.MARSHALL_ATTRS]) def to_json(self): return json.dumps(self.to_dict()) class DseTable(object): def __init__(self, service_id, table_id): self.service_id = service_id self.tabble_id = table_id self.topic = "congress-service-%s-table-%s" % (service_id, table_id) self.sub_seq = 0 self.pub_seq = 0 def drop_cast_echos(wrapped): @functools.wraps(wrapped) def wrapper(rpc_endpoint, message_context, *args, **kwargs): node = rpc_endpoint.node if False and message_context['node_id'] == node.node_id: LOG.trace("<%s> Ignoring my echo", node.node_id) return return wrapped(rpc_endpoint, message_context, *args, **kwargs) return wrapper class _DseNodeControlBus(object): """Maintain DSE connection for a DseNode. The DSE maintains a common directory of data services and their corresponding exported tables and RPCs. This control bus maintains this view using oslo.messaging RPC primitives. """ CONTROL_TOPIC = 'congress-control' HEARBEAT_INTERVAL = 1 class _DseControlBusEndpoint(object): def __init__(self, dse_bus): self.dse_bus = dse_bus self.node = dse_bus.node @drop_cast_echos def accept_heartbeat(self, client_ctxt, args): LOG.debug("<%s> Accepted heartbeat: context=%s, args='%s'", self.node.node_id, client_ctxt, args) hb = json.loads(args) peer_id = client_ctxt['node_id'] old_peer_status = self.dse_bus.peers.get(peer_id) if old_peer_status: pass # XXX validate else: # we currently only support 1 service per node service = hb['services'][0] self.dse_bus.peers[peer_id] = DataService.from_dict(service) LOG.info("<%s> New peer '%s' with service %s", self.node.node_id, peer_id, self.dse_bus.peers[peer_id]) # TODO: time going backwards self.dse_bus.peers[peer_id].last_hb_time = time.time() @drop_cast_echos def list_services(self, client_ctxt): # TODO: include service status [JOINING, JOINED] # Publish again when any peer discovery message is received LOG.debug("<%s> Peer '%s' requested updated service list", self.node.node_id, client_ctxt['node_id']) self.dse_bus._publish_heartbeat() # XXX is this necessary? @drop_cast_echos def list_topics(self, client_ctxt, args): return self.node.publish_topics() def __init__(self, node): """Initialize a control bus for a DseNode. Args: node: A DseNode to expose on the DSE control bus """ self.node = node self.transport = self.node.transport self.context = self.node.context target = messaging.Target(topic=self.CONTROL_TOPIC, version='1.0', fanout=True, server=self.node.node_id) self._client = messaging.RPCClient(self.transport, target) self._server = messaging.get_rpc_server( self.transport, target, [self._DseControlBusEndpoint(self)], executor='eventlet') self.peers = {} def _heartbeat_loop(self): while True: self._publish_heartbeat() eventlet.sleep(self.HEARBEAT_INTERVAL) def _publish_heartbeat(self): LOG.debug('<%s> Casting heartbeat to %s', self.node.node_id, self._client.target) args = json.dumps({'services': [self.node.service.to_dict()]}) self._client.cast(self.context, 'accept_heartbeat', args=args) def start(self): LOG.debug("<%s> Starting DSE control bus", self.node.node_id) self._server.start() # TODO: ensure I am not currently running # Add an instance uuid to the node status, have timeout on nodes # Request immediate status refresh from peers LOG.debug("<%s> Requesting service list from all peers", self.node.node_id) self._client.cast(self.context, 'list_services') # TODO: before enabling self, check if my node ID is already present eventlet.spawn(self._heartbeat_loop) def stop(self): self._server.stop() def wait(self): self._server.wait() def directory(self): return self.peers class MyStuff(object): def doStuff(self, client_ctxt, **kwargs): return 'hi %s %kw:s' % (str(self), str(kwargs)) class MyStuff2(object): def doStuff(self, client_ctxt, **kwargs): return 'hi(ms2) %s kw:%s' % (str(self), str(kwargs)) def doMoreStuff(self, client_ctxt, **kwargs): return 'hi(ms2more) %s kw:%s' % (str(self), str(kwargs)) class DseNode(object): """Addressable entity participating on the DSE message bus. The Data Services Engine (DSE) """ NODE_RPC_TOPIC = 'congress-control' @classmethod def node_rpc_topic(cls, node_id): return 'congress-rpc-%s' % node_id @classmethod def node_rpc_target(cls, node_id): topic = cls.node_rpc_topic(node_id) return messaging.Target(topic=topic, version='1.0', fanout=False, server=node_id) def __init__(self, messaging_config, node_id, service): """Initialize a new DSE Node. Args: messaging_config: configuration options for oslo.messaging node_id: A unique identifier used (by system and administrator) to identify this node service: A DataService to run on this node """ self.messaging_config = messaging_config self.node_id = node_id self.service = service self.service.node_id = self.node_id #self.instance = uuid.uuid4() # XXX self.instance = '1' # XXX self.context = self._message_context() self.transport = messaging.get_transport(self.messaging_config) self._control_bus = _DseNodeControlBus(self) #TODO: are RPC on service or node (both) target = self.node_rpc_target(self.node_id) self._server = messaging.get_rpc_server( self.transport, target, [MyStuff(), MyStuff2()], executor='eventlet') self._server.start() def __repr__(self): return self.__class__.__name__ + "<%s>" % self.node_id def __cmp__(self, other): return (cmp(self.node_id, other.node_id) or cmp(self.instance, other.instance)) def _message_context(self): return {'node_id': self.node_id, 'instance': str(self.instance)} # XXX getter, setter def _exported_tables(self): pass def start(self): """Start participating on the DSE. This method causes the DseNode to begin communicating with other nodes on the DSE. Once the node joins the DSE, it will begin receiving updates for tables it has subscribed to. Other nodes may subscribe to data exported by this node, and can also execute any RPCs that are exposed. """ LOG.info("Starting DSE node '%s'" % self.node_id) self._control_bus.start() def stop(self): """Stop participating on the DSE. """ LOG.info("Stopping DSE node '%s'" % self.node_id) self._control_bus.stop() def wait(self): """Wait for DSE participation to complete. """ self._control_bus.wait() def dse_status(self): """Return known status of nodes on DSE. """ # TODO: return nodes, last heartbeat, and status return self._control_bus.directory() def rpc_directory(self): """Return all known RPCs exposed on the DSE. """ # TODO: implement raise NotImplementedError() # TODO: rename node_id to service_id def invoke_rpc(self, node_id, method, **kwargs): """Invoke RPC method on a DSE Node. Args: node_id: The ID of the node on which to invoke the call. method: The method name to call. kwargs: A dict of method arguments. Raises: MessagingTimeout, RemoteError, MessageDeliveryFailure """ # TODO: implement target = self.node_rpc_target(node_id) print target client = messaging.RPCClient(self.transport, target) return client.call(self.context, method, **kwargs) raise NotImplementedError() def service_directory(self): """Return all services known on the DSE. Return is dict with the follwoing form: {node_id: {service: [], rpc: []}} """ return self._control_bus.directory().values() #TODO caller service id def subscribe(self, service_id, table_id): """Subscribe to updates for a table exported by a datasource. Args: service_id: The ID of the datasource to subscibe to. table_id: The ID of the table to subscribe to. """ # TODO: implement raise NotImplementedError() def unsubscribe(self, service_id, table_id): """Unsubscribe from updates for a table exported by a datasource. Args: service_id: The ID of the datasource to unsubscibe from. table_id: The ID of the table to unsubscribe from. """ # TODO: implement raise NotImplementedError() def monitor_dse(local_nodes, interval=5): # TODO: get total nodes and services; print node delta views # TODO: RPC to node to get their view i = 0 while True: all_nodes = set() all_services = set() for node in local_nodes: all_nodes.update(node.dse_status().keys()) all_services.update(node.service_directory()) print("--- DSE Status %s ---" % i) i += 1 print("Total Nodes(%s): %s" % (len(all_nodes), sorted(all_nodes))) svc_names = sorted(set([s.service_id for s in all_services])) print("Total Services(%s): %s" % (len(svc_names), svc_names)) for node in sorted(local_nodes): print node, node.dse_status().keys() #print 'calling' #a = node.invoke_rpc('node1.1', 'doMoreStuff', foo=3, bar="abc") #print 'done: %s' % a eventlet.sleep(interval) print # XXX debug prints here #from pprint import pprint #print self.node.node_id #pprint(self.peers) #print # XXX end debug prints def main(): config.init(sys.argv[1:]) if not cfg.CONF.config_file: sys.exit("ERROR: Unable to find configuration file via default " "search paths ~/.congress/, ~/, /etc/congress/, /etc/) and " "the '--config-file' option!") config.setup_logging() #LOG.logger.setLevel('DEBUG') # XXX use_fake = True if use_fake: from oslo_messaging import conffixture mc_fixture = conffixture.ConfFixture(cfg.CONF) mc_fixture.conf.transport_url = '' mc_fixture.transport_driver = 'fake' messaging_config = mc_fixture.conf else: messaging_config = cfg.CONF # end XXX #node_idss = [cfg.CONF.dse.node_id] node_ids = ["%s.%s" % (cfg.CONF.dse.node_id, i) for i in range(3)] nodes = [] for node_id in node_ids: service = DataService(node_id + '_svc') # XXX get from config node = DseNode(messaging_config, node_id, service) node.start() nodes.append(node) eventlet.spawn(monitor_dse, nodes) try: eventlet.sleep(1000) node.wait() node.stop() except KeyboardInterrupt: LOG.info("DseNode %s terminated by KeyboardInterrupt" % cfg.CONF.dse.node_id) if __name__ == '__main__': main()

subject: Prune old branches when updating cache
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-12 00:32:51.000000000', 'files': ['elements/source-repositories/extra-data.d/98-source-repositories'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/4573d0d930c070a113891709cb50972a8c4d1016', 'message': 'Prune old branches when updating cache

dib builds are failing in nodepool at the moment trying to download a
really old Fedora image.  What happens is that the devstack cache
script [1] goes through all the branches of the devstack checkout and
uses the inbuilt image-list tool [2] to get its list of images to
pre-download.  One of the old Fedora images required on the retired
branches has now gone, so the build halts with a 404 trying to get it.

Thus make sure we do a --prune when we fetch changes so that old
branches are removed from the cache.

[1] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/project-config/tree/nodepool/elements/cache-devstack/extra-data.d/55-cache-devstack-repos
[2] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-dev/devstack/tree/tools/image_list.sh

Change-Id: Ieb6a6e9f55bd93f63c3d0a71828c276c2d02e1b9
'}]
commit_message:
Prune old branches when updating cache

dib builds are failing in nodepool at the moment trying to download a
really old Fedora image.  What happens is that the devstack cache
script [1] goes through all the branches of the devstack checkout and
uses the inbuilt image-list tool [2] to get its list of images to
pre-download.  One of the old Fedora images required on the retired
branches has now gone, so the build halts with a 404 trying to get it.

Thus make sure we do a --prune when we fetch changes so that old
branches are removed from the cache.

[1] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/project-config/tree/nodepool/elements/cache-devstack/extra-data.d/55-cache-devstack-repos
[2] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-dev/devstack/tree/tools/image_list.sh

Change-Id: Ieb6a6e9f55bd93f63c3d0a71828c276c2d02e1b9

commit_message:
Create dse2.DataService class

DataServices represent components on the DSE that expose and/or
consume data tables.  In future commits, DataServices will be extended
to support RPC and policy delegation.

Partially-implements: blueprint dist-cross-process-dse
Change-Id: I02552db565c3bdab60acb330122579f0097de088

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2015 VMware, Inc. All rights reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # import json import time from congress.dse2.dataservice import DataService from congress.tests import base class TestDataService(base.TestCase): TESTDATA = {'service_id': 'test-service-id', 'node_id': 'test-node-id', 'published_tables': ['t1', 't2'], 'subscribed_tables': ['s1', 's2', 's3']} def test_from_json(self): s = DataService.from_json(json.dumps(self.TESTDATA)) for a in DataService.MARSHALL_ATTRS: self.assertEqual(getattr(s, a), self.TESTDATA[a], "Attr '%s' set properly in from_dict" % a) self.assertRaises(KeyError, DataService.from_json, '{"bad_attr": 123}') def test_to_json(self): s = DataService(**self.TESTDATA) self.assertEqual(json.loads(s.to_json()), self.TESTDATA, 'JSON representation matches constructed data') s.last_hb_time = time.time() self.assertEqual(json.loads(s.to_json()), self.TESTDATA, 'JSON representation ignores last_hb_time') def test_from_dict(self): s = DataService.from_dict(self.TESTDATA) for a in DataService.MARSHALL_ATTRS: self.assertEqual(getattr(s, a), self.TESTDATA[a], "Attr '%s' set properly in from_dict" % a) self.assertRaises(KeyError, DataService.from_dict, {'bad_attr': 123}) def test_to_dict(self): s = DataService(**self.TESTDATA) self.assertEqual(s.to_dict(), self.TESTDATA, 'dict representation matches constructed data') s.last_hb_time = time.time() self.assertEqual(s.to_dict(), self.TESTDATA, 'dict representation ignores last_hb_time') # TODO(pballand): replace with congress unit test framework when convenient if __name__ == '__main__': import unittest unittest.main(verbosity=2)

commit_message:
Fix for the deprecated library function

os.popen() is deprecated since version 2.6. Resolved with use of
subprocess module.

Change-Id: Ie7e0cf06fb5f6a40984a24b3c9123187c0a3a3cc

commit_message:
Some additional engine logging

Add more trace logging that can be useful to log
when things start to work in the wrong way (which
can sometimes happen).

Change-Id: I7f36735d29c94e382f790feef283e538a9a6a8ff

commit_message:
Add constraints to tox targets

This change allows gate job to support upper-constraints.
Currently constraints based job is as experimental.
We switch nonconstraints based job in liberty and later branch,
if they are stable.

This patch is cherry-picked from master branch but it must get
the upper-constraints.txt file from stable/liberty branch.

Related Change-Id: I699022b285594edf3c5db10fbdac2f904dc42928
Change-Id: I4175762e850fdfa1f715ca301d74492802b2490e
(cherry picked from commit 565b7b59c47cb1a02b6d1330310d9de8b00195f2)

commit_message:
Add libjpeg and liberasurecode for tests

Pilow needs libjpeg and liberasurecode is needed by PyECLib. In the
future we should be able to get this done with bindep, but we're not
quite there yet.

commit_message:
Murano engine package cache spec

Targets blueprint: murano-engine-package-cache

Change-Id: I340b0f82cbc8cee9f308f4fc98d6a4800d793961
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-specs refs/changes/07/259007/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================== Engine Package Cache ==================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/murano/+spec/murano-engine-package-cache This specification provides means to improve caching of packages to fasten consecutive deployments and action executions, that use the same package. Problem description =================== When murano-engine performs a deployment or executes an action on a deployed environment it needs access to the code of the package. Currently it downloads a package from API for each deployment and stores it in a local cache fr the duration of the deployment, but deletes it after the deployment has finished. This means, that a consecutive deployment of the environment that uses the same package would have to download it again. Same is true for actions. This puts an undesired strain on murano-api and network, as the same package is downloaded many times even if it didn't change Currently murano-engine stores packages on disc, using package-id as cache key. This further means that if two environments are using the same package the first to finish would delete the cache, leaving the second environment in an unexpected state. This can potentially lead to unexpected and hard to pinpoint bugs. Among other things the cache system should be able to satisfy and correctly work around the following corner cases: #. Several different versions of single package may be used simultaneously by parallel deployments/actions. #. Package may be deleted or re-uploaded to API (with or without version change) while there are ongoing deployments that use previous package version. #. Deployment/action may require to download the package that is currently being downloaded for another deployment/action. #. Packages might need to be eventually invalidated and space constrained. Generally there are 2 situation when a package cache needs to be invalidated: #. A new package of the same version and FQN has been updated, meaning old one is no longer available, but might still be used by an ongoing deployment #. A package has not been used for long time (but may be exactly the same as the most recent package in the API) Proposed change =============== Proposed change includes modifying current cache mechanism to allow it to persist the packages on disk and not clean them up after deployment/action has ended. #. Change cache storage directory path from {id} to {fqn}/{version}/{id} This would allow to easily detect outdated versions of the same package #. Whenever engine starts executing a task it would acquire shared *usage* lock on 2 levels: eventlet-based lock, (to synchronise tasks from the current execution task with other execution tasks) and file-system based lock, using flock or similar primitives (to synchronise use of package cache between different murano-engine processes). The lock should be released after the package is no longer required. #. If the package is not available in cache execution task would attempt to acquire exclusive *download* lock on 2 levels (eventlet/file-based), thus allowing only one download per id at a time. The lock should be released after the download is finished. #. The task, downloading the package would be the one responsible for deleting outdated versions of the same package. To do so it would acquire exclusive *usage* lock on 2 levels for the packages it wishes to delete as part of cleanup. This would ensure, that ongoing deployments would not be affected by the cleanup. Limitations ----------- This spec only aims to address the problem of invalidating package cache of packages, that are outdated. Solving the problem of invalidating of packages, that have not been used in a while requires a separate cache-manager, process/service, which in turn would require additional more fine grained locks to be implemented and it doesn't look like a real problem right now as the size of the packages is relatively small and the number of packages in a typical murano installation is not that large to consume all of the space on the server. However we should be aware of this situation and probably work on that solution some time in the future. Alternatives ------------ One of the alternatives would be to add HTTP headers for caching control, for example If-Modified-Since. While this is a good idea as of itself it would impact murano-api, python-muranoclient and murano-engine, thus making it a lot harder to implement and test. Instead of having 2-layer locking we could implement spin-locks around file locks, which doesn't look like a good idea though. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Versioning impact ------------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Deployer impact --------------- Since package cache would persist on disk — it would be possible to drain disk resources by it. This is still possible to do today by creating a really large amount of simultaneous deployments, although in the current situation the package cache would be eventually deleted, and space would be reclaimed. If we believe that this is a serious security flaw — we need to implement cache invalidation/caps of max cache storage before M release Developer impact ---------------- None Murano-dashboard / Horizon impact --------------------------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: kzaitsev Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Looks like unit tests would be enough for proper coverage Documentation Impact ==================== Usual docs update required References ==========

commit_message:
Use SpawnIsSynchronousFixture in most unit tests

SpawnIsSynchronousFixture is introduced in 90fb490a
this patch try to use the fixture and remove unnessary mocks
in compute layer test cases.

Change-Id: Idaedb9558b0aec047f0583c0593331a634cc59a2

commit_message:
Remove DictCompat from EC2 objects

This changes over all occurrences of dictionary syntax on the
EC2InstanceMapping, EC2VolumeMapping, and EC2SnapshotMapping objects
to use object syntax.

Change-Id: I74eb3ba202c699c845745174716e2d5a11c21cb9
Partially-Implements: bp rm-object-dict-compat
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/33/265933/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class EC2InstanceMapping(base.NovaPersistentObject, base.NovaObject): setattr(imap, field, db_imap[field])class EC2VolumeMapping(base.NovaPersistentObject, base.NovaObject): setattr(vmap, field, db_vmap[field])class EC2SnapshotMapping(base.NovaPersistentObject, base.NovaObject): setattr(smap, field, db_smap[field])
deleted_lines: # TODO(berrange): Remove NovaObjectDictCompatclass EC2InstanceMapping(base.NovaPersistentObject, base.NovaObject, base.NovaObjectDictCompat): imap[field] = db_imap[field]# TODO(berrange): Remove NovaObjectDictCompatclass EC2VolumeMapping(base.NovaPersistentObject, base.NovaObject, base.NovaObjectDictCompat): vmap[field] = db_vmap[field]# TODO(berrange): Remove NovaObjectDictCompatclass EC2SnapshotMapping(base.NovaPersistentObject, base.NovaObject, base.NovaObjectDictCompat): smap[field] = db_smap[field]

commit_message:
Fix provider_net resource update

This changes handle_update to use prop_diff for update.

Change-Id: I7b1503962b528e629016144e798227f74f7a6ba8
Partial-Bug: #1521836
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/92/252192/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def prepare_provider_properties(props): if ProviderNet.PROVIDER_NETWORK_TYPE in props: ProviderNet.add_provider_extension( props, ProviderNet.PROVIDER_NETWORK_TYPE) if ProviderNet.PROVIDER_PHYSICAL_NETWORK in props: ProviderNet.add_provider_extension( props, ProviderNet.PROVIDER_PHYSICAL_NETWORK) if ProviderNet.PROVIDER_SEGMENTATION_ID in props: ProviderNet.add_provider_extension( props, ProviderNet.PROVIDER_SEGMENTATION_ID) ProviderNet.prepare_provider_properties(props) if prop_diff: ProviderNet.prepare_provider_properties(prop_diff) self.client().update_network(self.resource_id, {'network': prop_diff})
deleted_lines: import six def prepare_provider_properties(self, props): self.add_provider_extension(props, self.PROVIDER_NETWORK_TYPE) self.add_provider_extension(props, self.PROVIDER_PHYSICAL_NETWORK) if self.PROVIDER_SEGMENTATION_ID in six.iterkeys(props): self.add_provider_extension(props, self.PROVIDER_SEGMENTATION_ID) self.prepare_provider_properties(self, props) props = self.prepare_update_properties(json_snippet) self.prepare_provider_properties(self, props) self.client().update_network(self.resource_id, {'network': props})

commit_message:
XtremIO fix attach readonly bug

* Remove the access_mode from connection_info and let the manager decide
on the access mode.
* add a test to make sure access_mode won't be added in the future

liberty-backport-potential

Change-Id: I1584b27ff0c14e54f1d1efb2310d25454995c50a
Closes-Bug: 1516365
(cherry picked from commit 487ca0aa6940ce1bafd67a66107e0da7aabb2749)

commit_message:
Move defaults.rb to openstack spec helper

This change is to add the defaults.rb to the openstack spec helper so we
have a single place that can be referenced by all the modules to provide
our default facts.

Change-Id: I0e103b1782b02f22f6f9c37658da1e386312a27d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack_spec_helper refs/changes/85/267185/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # This file contains a module to return a default set of facts and supported # operating systems for the tests in this module. module OSDefaults def self.get_facts(extra_facts={}) { :os_service_default => '<SERVICE DEFAULT>' }.merge(extra_facts) end def self.get_supported_os [ { 'operatingsystem' => 'CentOS', 'operatingsystemrelease' => [ '7.0' ] }, { 'operatingsystem' => 'RedHat', 'operatingsystemrelease' => [ '7.0' ] }, { 'operatingsystem' => 'Fedora', 'operatingsystemrelease' => [ '21', '22' ] }, { 'operatingsystem' => 'Ubuntu', 'operatingsystemrelease' => [ '14.04' ] }, { 'operatingsystem' => 'Debian', 'operatingsystemrelease' => [ '7', '8' ] } ] end end

If the tests are run without neurton enabled the shared_network is not
set and left as "%shared_network%" in the config file. This is read

'}]
commit_message:
fix scenario test where shared_network is not available

If the tests are run without neurton enabled the shared_network is not
set and left as "%shared_network%" in the config file. This is read
and passed into the create call as the net-id and nova fails the
create call because "%shared_network%" doesnt exist.

Change-Id: I9ec7edb4724c744c665f404a8f67e3e0119be2eb

commit_message:
Replace "suspend" with "destroy" in failover cases

Snapshot with error after suspending node contains suspended node
which will be starter after dos.py revert-resume.
"Destroy" should be used in this cases.

Change-Id: If5146412bc33a74f7f7196bf496d2760c73925a7
Closes-bug:#1532748
(cherry picked from commit 214d6addce22242dad65d3ad9c901d29f51460a2)

commit_message:
Drop l3 directory.

This directory was created at the beginning of the project but was never
used.  The l3 support is in plugin.py.

Closes-bug: 1514998
Change-Id: I35ebfef399aaf82212bb229f6c3f3c26b01b67c7
Signed-off-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>

deleted_lines: exec() ===================== The [python docs](https://docs.python.org/2.0/ref/exec.html) succinctly describe why ```exec()``` is bad: * "This statement supports dynamic execution of Python code." ### Correct Look for alternate solutions than ```exec```; often times you can find other modules or builtins to complete the task securely. If ```exec``` is absolutely necessary, extreme care must be taken to ensure no untrusted input is included in the expression that ```exec``` evaluates. ### Incorrect A common use case is to to read a file and then exec the content to execute Python within your currently running script, e.g: ```python exec( open('setup.py','rb').read() ) ``` That is obviously scary because you are executing the Python code in setup.py. Another example that is even more scary is a practice similar to: ```python exec 'from ' + mod_name + ' import test' ``` If we set mod_name to ```unittest```, everything works normally. However, if we set mod_name to ```unittest import test; import ast #``` we've successfully imported a module that the developer did not intend. ## Consequences * Unintended code execution ## References * [0] https://docs.python.org/2.0/ref/exec.html

commit_message:
Replaces __builtin__ with six.moves.builtins

__builtin__ does not exist in Python 3. Replacing it with
six.moves.builtins will ensure compatibility with both Python 2.7
and Python 3.4.

Partially implements blueprint: nova-python3-mitaka

Change-Id: If99c9670644f95e2b5c37d14fad491d829850f36

commit_message:
Standardize bashate and add linters

The linters gate combindes pep8 and bashate (and then any other
linters we want). This changes bashate to be a sript rather than doing
a script inline. This matches the way other projects (and
project-config themselves) uses bashate [1].

Once a change upstream merges we can remove the redundant pep8 and
bashate gates.

[1] https://github.com/openstack-infra/project-config/blob/master/tox.ini#L11
https://github.com/openstack-infra/project-config/blob/master/tools/run-bashate.sh

Related-Id: I2afa7931bf3e18798b95a8af33ccf5ef761c4ad5

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I2ea2c1156e1b4de008f19e333e2740795dc406de

subject: Fix possible race condition when loading recent runs.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-13 20:44:54.000000000', 'files': ['app/js/controllers/job.js', 'app/js/controllers/grouped-runs.js'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-health/commit/f0bbb34ebe2ab38784fa51375dea999bc6217604', 'message': 'Fix possible race condition when loading recent runs.

The list of recent runs currently is not initialized to its default
value until processData() has completed. If the request for recent
runs happens to finish first, it can throw an error when attempting
to modify the array. This moves the array initialization to the
beginning of the function, and allocates it directly in the request

Change-Id: Id8aec75d2233617322f9ac24fdb1904f0b46f846
'}]
commit_message:
Fix possible race condition when loading recent runs.

The list of recent runs currently is not initialized to its default
value until processData() has completed. If the request for recent
runs happens to finish first, it can throw an error when attempting
to modify the array. This moves the array initialization to the
beginning of the function, and allocates it directly in the request
handler to prevent the error from occurring.

Change-Id: Id8aec75d2233617322f9ac24fdb1904f0b46f846
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-health refs/changes/57/267157/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Revert "Use assertTrue/False instead of assertEqual(T/F)"

assertFalse() is a weaker assertion than assertEqual(False, xxx),
because the former will allow None while the latter will not.

assertEqual is correct choice in a fair number of cases.

This reverts commit 7f00e710cf0ac2f0f9c18b058e3badbb7ec1c0cf.

Change-Id: I115964b3f8fa0fa6d1bb5787b70a61a14b254348

commit_message:
Sets binding:profile to empty dic when unbinding port

When binding preexisting ports, direct/macvtap, nova
adds the binding:profile information. But when deleting
the VM, the port binding:profile information still kept.

This patch sets binding:profile to empty dic when unbinding it.

Closes-Bug: #1524643

Change-Id: I127e88a9bcdad44b795a245e566ab276de09fd82
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/69/261369/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: body['port']['binding:profile'] = {}

commit_message:
Remove work around for NullHandler

logging module added NullHandler in Python 2.7, we have
dropped Python 2.6 support now, so don't need the work around
any more.

Change-Id: Ib6fdbc2f92cd66f4846243221e696f1b1fa712df
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/stevedore refs/changes/44/266644/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LOG.addHandler(logging.NullHandler())
deleted_lines: if hasattr(logging, 'NullHandler'): LOG.addHandler(logging.NullHandler()) else: class NullHandler(logging.Handler): def handle(self, record): pass def emit(self, record): pass def createLock(self): self.lock = None LOG.addHandler(NullHandler())

commit_message:
Fix error when test setup fails to produce the required metrics

Cannot use method fail() in a class method
Added quick fail to two other test groups
Added some detail to setup failure messages

Change-Id: I47deae35feea1b50916d8820334f30e2bb8f2cba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-api refs/changes/01/259501/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: assert False, 'Unable to initialize metrics'
deleted_lines: cls.fail('Unable to initialize metrics')

commit_message:
Support `truncated` flag returned by keystone

Wrap a list of objects into custom class with additional attributes.

This is wanted by Horizon, that wants to know that the list returned
from keystone is not full and that more strict filters need to be
applied.

Change-Id: Icfabfd055aed1648dc4130b03ec3dbf9bad4e45a
Closes-Bug: 1520244
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/73/250473/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import collectionsclass KeystoneReturnedList(collections.Sequence): """A list of entities with additional attributes.""" def __init__(self, collection, truncated=False): self.collection = collection self.truncated = truncated def __getitem__(self, i): return self.collection[i] def __len__(self): return len(self.collection) truncated = body.get('truncated', False) objects = [obj_class(self, res, loaded=True) for res in data if res] return KeystoneReturnedList(objects, truncated=truncated)
deleted_lines: return [obj_class(self, res, loaded=True) for res in data if res]

commit_message:
Add axis to the timeline viewport.

This adds a labeled time axis to the main viewport chart. Previously
time was only displayed as part of the cursor, but now it is also
visible at all times on the chart itself.

Change-Id: I8f2379ef50a1d4f4ea2869aa26f1a7e5744bdb8a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/stackviz refs/changes/73/265473/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: timeline-viewport svg { .axis { shape-rendering: crispEdges; path { fill: none; stroke: lightgray; } line { fill: none; stroke: lightgray; } text { font: 9px sans-serif; fill: #888; } } }

commit_message:
Add search and filtering support to the timeline.

This adds a new UI for searching and filtering through tests in a
timeline. A new dropdown for filter options is added to the timeline
panel header, where users can query and select tests based on name and
metadata (pass/fail/skip). A list of results is displayed which can
be selected from directly, but results are also highlighted on the
timeline directly.

Some rearchitecting of the HTML layout for the timeline directive was
needed to allow part of the timeline to be inside a panel header, so
the entire panel layout was moved inside the timeline directive.
A new `filterFunction` field was added to the main timeline controller
to support communicating the filtering parameters to other components
of the timeline. Additionally, a new `contextClass` filter was added
to avoid excessive code duplication for highlighting element color
based on test status - existing uses were replaced with this.

Change-Id: I5f35091ab2b605e0821125e79de47c4c6067f644
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/stackviz refs/changes/91/266091/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: timeline-viewport svg { .filter-hit { } .filter-miss { opacity: 0.15; } }

commit_message:
Update Angular and UI Bootstrap to latest versions.

This updates `angular` and `angular-ui-bootstrap` to their latest
versions. Upcoming changes rely on several bugfixes and features
introduced in the newer versions, and this should encompass all of
the necessary preparation.

Change-Id: Iddc210ef64e913babbbd409747fecf3bbd8f2d5e

deleted_lines: "angular": "^1.3.15", "angular-mocks": "^1.3.15", "angular-ui-bootstrap": "^0.13.3", "angular-ui-router": "^0.2.13", "dependencies": {}

commit_message:
Redesign the timeline details panel.

This redesigns the aspects of the timeline, particularly relating to
the details panel. First, selection mechanics are greatly simplified,
so items can be hovered while one is selected. Additionally, hovered
item names are now shown as part of the cursor. The details panel
now only shows details for selected items, and is moved to fill the
bottom of the screen; similarly, the timeline now fills the full width
of the screen.

Change-Id: I0acb88f898dcfd0a0327a38aa5eb995f118e1a1e

commit_message:
Don't call add_ha_port inside a transaction

Calling add_ha_port inside a transaction will break the delete_port
error recovery logic. This patch prevents the scheduler from doing
that. It also adds a note to add_ha_port and a runtime check to
prevent the function from working with an active transaction.

Change-Id: I39e2bb70527a8ff4a47668f44abb81d0fede3786
Closes-Bug: #1529037

commit_message:
Add setters for derived attributes to Atom (WIP)

Attributes that get derived from arguments passed
to the constructor cannot currently be changed after
the fact.  This is a somewhat hacky approach to the
problem in that the public API hasn't changed, but
setting any of the attributes re-computes the actual
values.  This lets you do stuff like:

atom = Task('mytask')
atom.provides = ['a', 'b']

And it works as expected.  'provides', 'requires', 'rebind',
and 'optional' all can now be set and work as expected.

Change-Id: I9a325fc91944b0ad406ab2e96137f306b8e732e8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/30/264930/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use pymysql database driver for OpenStack DBs

PyMySQL is a new driver introduced in Liberty.
This patch change the MySQL url to use mysql+pymysql like recommanded.

Closes-Bug: #1499298
Depends-On: I7604cca9e2d7bf0b93c820adec5f937f72b64fa8
Change-Id: I1b49a86f0bb4b410620e280b7e53c32c5186b1f7

commit_message:
Move Grafana to Apache's DocumentRoot

Static files are normally deployed with django's 'manage.py collectstatic'.
When run with --clear option, which seems to be default in some distributions
(e.g. RDO), all static resources are deleted first. Current Horizon integration
creates link to Grafana in static directory. Runing collectstatic --clear
leaves Grafana corrupted.

Proposed solution: Move Grafana to Apache's DocumentRoot.

also see: https://github.com/hpcloud-mon/ansible-monasca-ui/pull/6

Change-Id: Icbb2eecd45dfb1da48f63464ac83acb9e06cd71f

commit_message:
Force releasenotes warnings to be treated as errors

Ensure the releasenotes can always be built and rendered properly.

http://sphinx-doc.org/man/sphinx-build.html?highlight=-W

Change-Id: I2fbe7ab362adc88c3fb7694fcf05ff614a07d6b7

commit_message:
Add scripts/upload-swift-artifacts

This patch adds a new script/tool that can be used to upload
a set of file(s) into Swift. The tool automatically creates and
configures a Swift Temp URL in the undercloud and then generates
the required heat environment in $HOME/.tripleo/environments/ so that it
will automatically be used by heat deployments.

Change-Id: If63260e59ae44b172a76222d591d4e62d9432655
Implements: blueprint puppet-modules-deployment-via-swift
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/10/245310/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash # Copyright 2015 Red Hat, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # # Script to upload directory tarball of puppet modules to a swift container. # set -eu set -o pipefail SCRIPT_NAME=$(basename $0) SCRIPT_HOME=$(cd $(dirname $0); pwd) function show_options { echo "Usage: $SCRIPT_NAME <directory>" echo echo "Options:" echo " -h, --help -- print this help." echo " -d <directory> -- Puppet modules directory. Required." echo " -c <container> -- Swift container to use." echo " Default: overcloud" echo " --environment <env> -- Generate this heat <env>" echo " Default: $HOME/.tripleo/environments/puppet-modules-url.yaml" echo " --seconds <seconds> -- Number of seconds for temp URL." echo " Default: 31536000 (one year)" echo echo "Upload a directory tarball of puppet modules to a swift container" echo "and generate a heat environment file containing the required" echo "PuppetModulesURL parameter so that it is used for TripleO deployment." echo exit $1 } TEMP=`getopt -o h:ed:c: -l help,environment:,directory:,container: -n $SCRIPT_NAME -- "$@"` if [ $? != 0 ]; then echo "Terminating..." >&2 exit 1 fi # Note the quotes around `$TEMP': they are essential! eval set -- "$TEMP" ENVIRONMENT_FILE="$HOME/.tripleo/environments/puppet-modules-url.yaml" MODULES_DIRECTORY= CONTAINER_NAME=overcloud SECONDS=31536000 while true ; do case "$1" in -h|--help) show_options 0 >&2;; -e|--environment) ENVIRONMENT_FILE=$2 ; shift 2;; -d|--directory) MODULES_DIRECTORY=$2 ; shift 2;; -c|--container) CONTAINER_NAME=$2 ; shift 2;; -s|--seconds) SECONDS=$2 ; shift 2;; --) shift ; break;; *) echo "Error: unsupported option $1." ; exit 1;; esac done if [ -z "${MODULES_DIRECTORY:-}" ]; then echo "Error: No Puppet modules --directory was specified." exit 1 fi if [ -z "${CONTAINER_NAME:-}" ]; then echo "Error: No swift --container was specified." exit 1 fi function create_heat_env() { local heat_env_file=$1 local puppet_modules_url=$2 mkdir -p $(dirname "$heat_env_file") cat > "$heat_env_file" <<-EOF_CAT # Heat environment which sets the current puppet modules URL to a Swift Temp URL parameter_defaults: PuppetModulesURL: $puppet_modules_url EOF_CAT } # create the container (doing it more than once won't hurt...) swift post "$CONTAINER_NAME" SWIFT_ACCOUNT=$(swift stat "$CONTAINER_NAME" 2>/dev/null | grep Account: | sed -e "s|.*Account..||") SWIFT_INTERNAL_URL=$(openstack endpoint show swift | grep internalurl | sed -e "s|.*\(http.*\)://\([^/]*\)/.*|\1://\2|") # Does the Temp-URL-Key exist on this container? # If not set it... if ! swift stat $CONTAINER_NAME | grep "Meta Temp-Url-Key" &>/dev/null; then echo "Creating new Swift Temp-URL-Key for container: $CONTAINER_NAME" SWIFT_TEMP_URL_KEY=$(uuidgen | sha1sum | awk '{print $1}') swift post "$CONTAINER_NAME" -m "Temp-URL-Key:$SWIFT_TEMP_URL_KEY" else SWIFT_TEMP_URL_KEY=$(swift stat $CONTAINER_NAME 2>/dev/null | grep "Meta Temp-Url-Key" | sed -e "s|.*Meta Temp-Url-Key..||") fi echo "Creating tarball..." PUPPET_MODULES_TMP=$(mktemp) rm "$PUPPET_MODULES_TMP" mkdir -p "$PUPPET_MODULES_TMP" tar -C $MODULES_DIRECTORY -czf "$PUPPET_MODULES_TMP/puppet-modules.tar.gz" . echo "Tarball created." #upload the actual data echo "Uploading to swift..." pushd $PUPPET_MODULES_TMP &>/dev/null swift upload "$CONTAINER_NAME" "puppet-modules.tar.gz" popd &>/dev/null rm -Rf "$PUPPET_MODULES_TMP" echo "Upload complete." PUPPET_MODULES_URL=$(swift-temp-url GET "$SECONDS" "/v1/${SWIFT_ACCOUNT}/${CONTAINER_NAME}/puppet-modules.tar.gz" "$SWIFT_TEMP_URL_KEY") if [ -n "${ENVIRONMENT_FILE:-}" ]; then echo "Creating heat environment file: $ENVIRONMENT_FILE" create_heat_env "$ENVIRONMENT_FILE" "${SWIFT_INTERNAL_URL}${PUPPET_MODULES_URL}" else echo "No environment file specified... skipping creation of Heat environment." fi

commit_message:
Pass version arg by name not position

Everyone except neutron has a first parameter called "version" - so we
can pass it by name. For neutron, add a workaround, becuase YAY people
being different.

Change-Id: Icfd92e5e31763ffccc1ff673298f89d1888941fe

commit_message:
Report discard support for Dell SC connections

Add reporting of discard in the properties returned from
initialize_connection. Dell SC arrays support trim/discard
with no special configuration needed, so this can always
be set to true.

Change-Id: Ib0136369e230b5219b2b3994d17b6b31a9aba69f

commit_message:
Only token or creds are required.

When token is provided and not the endpoint,
the client works, because keystoneauth/keystoneclient will
use the service_type to discover the endpoint.

Closes-bug: #1533712
Change-Id: I0cf1ba52f656a450d358b2356df67d004f9aba7d

deleted_lines: no_auth = has_token and self.opts.get('endpoint') missing = not (no_auth or has_credential)

commit_message:
Handle absence of cinder default volume type

The code previously did not set the default_vol_type attribute if the
fetch of the default volume type failed (because none is declared in
the service). This patch defaults the attribute to the expected None
value, allowing volume creation to continue.

Change-Id: Ic9e14ae4cb23023a270ad4aec4e1a830a11215dd
Fixes-Bug: 1518844
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/31/248531/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.default_vol_type = None

commit_message:
DVR: handle dvr serviceable port's host change

When a VM port's host is changed we need to check if a router
should be unscheduled from old host and send corresponding
notifications.
commit d5a8074ec3c67ed68e64a96827da990f1c34e10f added such
a check when port is unbound. This patch adds similar check
in case of host change (instance live migration)

Closes-Bug: #1508869

Conflicts:

	neutron/tests/functional/services/l3_router/test_l3_dvr_router_plugin.py

Change-Id: I57fa8253b2c88f7b7380a79b841fc424e9e52f19
(cherry picked from commit 189a6f1bc3295b719304f44e5b731ef671fe7f50)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/60/259960/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # register l3 agents in dvr mode in addition to existing dvr_snat agent HOST1 = 'host1' dvr_agent1 = helpers.register_l3_agent( host=HOST1, agent_mode=l3_const.L3_AGENT_MODE_DVR) HOST2 = 'host2' dvr_agent2 = helpers.register_l3_agent( host=HOST2, agent_mode=l3_const.L3_AGENT_MODE_DVR) self.context, router['id'])['agents'] self.assertEqual(1, len(agents)) self.assertEqual(self.l3_agent['id'], agents[0]['id']) self.l3_plugin.agent_notifiers[ l3_const.AGENT_TYPE_L3] = l3_notifier {'port': {'binding:host_id': HOST1}}) # now router should be scheduled to dvr_snat agent and # dvr agent on host1 self.context, router['id'])['agents'] self.assertEqual(2, len(agents)) self.assertIn(dvr_agent1['id'], [agent['id'] for agent in agents]) self.assertNotIn(dvr_agent2['id'], [agent['id'] for agent in agents]) # and notification should only be sent to the agent on host1 self.context, {router['id']}, HOST1) # updating port's host (instance migration) l3_notifier.reset_mock() self.core_plugin.update_port( self.context, port['port']['id'], {'port': {'binding:host_id': HOST2}}) # now router should be scheduled to dvr_snat agent and # dvr agent on host2 agents = self.l3_plugin.list_l3_agents_hosting_router( self.context, router['id'])['agents'] self.assertEqual(2, len(agents)) self.assertIn(dvr_agent2['id'], [agent['id'] for agent in agents]) self.assertNotIn(dvr_agent1['id'], [agent['id'] for agent in agents]) l3_notifier.routers_updated_on_host.assert_called_once_with( self.context, {router['id']}, HOST2) l3_notifier.router_removed_from_agent.assert_called_once_with( self.context, router['id'], HOST1)
deleted_lines: # register l3 agent in dvr mode in addition to existing dvr_snat agent HOST = 'host1' dvr_agent = helpers.register_l3_agent( host=HOST, agent_mode=l3_const.L3_AGENT_MODE_DVR) self.context, router['id']) self.assertEqual(1, len(agents['agents'])) self.assertEqual(self.l3_agent['id'], agents['agents'][0]['id']) {'port': {'binding:host_id': HOST}}) # now router should be scheduled to both agents self.context, router['id']) self.assertEqual(2, len(agents['agents'])) self.assertIn(dvr_agent['id'], [agent['id'] for agent in agents['agents']]) # and notification should only be sent to the agent on HOST self.context, {router['id']}, HOST)

subject: Fix a precedence problem with auth arguments
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-13 18:45:48.000000000', 'files': ['os_client_config/config.py', 'os_client_config/tests/test_config.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-client-config/commit/a8532f6c8d221628b697ddb0d134e2a000ef61d6', 'message': "Fix a precedence problem with auth arguments

With the current code, OS_TENANT_NAME will take precednece over
--os-project-name beause OS_TENANT_NAME gets early-moved to
config['auth']['project_name'], then when the argparse value gets put
into config['project_name'] the auth fixing sees auth['project_name']
and thinks it should win.

Change-Id: I97084ea221eb963f14d98cf550a04bbd5c7d954c
"}]
commit_message:
Fix a precedence problem with auth arguments

With the current code, OS_TENANT_NAME will take precednece over
--os-project-name beause OS_TENANT_NAME gets early-moved to
config['auth']['project_name'], then when the argparse value gets put
into config['project_name'] the auth fixing sees auth['project_name']
and thinks it should win.

Change-Id: I97084ea221eb963f14d98cf550a04bbd5c7d954c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-client-config refs/changes/92/267092/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_env_argparse_precedence(self): self.useFixture(fixtures.EnvironmentVariable( 'OS_TENANT_NAME', 'tenants-are-bad')) c = config.OpenStackConfig(config_files=[self.cloud_yaml], vendor_files=[self.vendor_yaml]) cc = c.get_one_cloud( cloud='envvars', argparse=self.options) self.assertEqual(cc.auth['project_name'], 'project')

subject: Return empty dict instead of None for lack of file
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-04 19:00:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-client-config/commit/623b097b028fae1a4cf41e7c8d2474bdc7f11cee', 'message': 'Return empty dict instead of None for lack of file

We return None for the file content for non-existent files as a
fallback. This is normally fine, but in the case of a person having
_only_ a secure.conf file, this means that the dictionary merge fails.

Change-Id: I61cc0a8c709ea3510428fc3dfce63dc254c07c83

commit_message:
Return empty dict instead of None for lack of file

We return None for the file content for non-existent files as a
fallback. This is normally fine, but in the case of a person having
_only_ a secure.conf file, this means that the dictionary merge fails.

Change-Id: I61cc0a8c709ea3510428fc3dfce63dc254c07c83
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-client-config refs/changes/95/263395/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: return (None, None)

commit_message:
Add ConsistencyGroupStatus enum field

This change adds a new enum and field, ConsistencyGroupStatus and
ConsistencyGroupStatusField, that will hold the constants for the
'status' field of the ConsistencyGroup object. This enum and field
are based off the base oslo.versionedobjects enum and field. This
also changes over the ConsistencyGroup object to use the new field
(and bumps the version so newer versions know to enforce
valid values). Finally, all uses of strings for comparison and
assignment to this field are changed over to use the constants
defined within the enum.

Change-Id: Icee2727f0a550541876c63b6e7340acf3de553c8
Implements:  bp cinder-object-fields

commit_message:
Replaced the existing Dockerfiles. Tidied up Readme

I replaced the Dockerfiles that existed, which pulled anchor
down from git with a single Dockerfile that uses the local version
of anchor.

This makes testing local changes to anchor very simple.

I also updated the README to reflect these changes and fixed the
varying line lenghts within that file.

Change-Id: I313c840f594639e6c92ed6ff067da79652b74ed0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/anchor refs/changes/22/267122/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: A critical capability within PKI is to revoke a certificate - to ensure that it is no longer trusted by any peer. Unfortunately research has demonstrated that the two typical methods of revocation (Certificate Revocation Lists and Online Certificate Status Protocol) both have failings that make them unreliable, especially when attempting to leverage PKI outside of web-browser software. Through the use of short-lifetime certificates Anchor introduces the concept of "passive revocation". By issuing certificates with lifetimes measured in hours, revocation can be achieved by simply not re-issuing certificates to clients. The benefits of using Anchor instead of manual long-term certificates are:In order to install Anchor from source, the following system dependencies need to be present:When everything is in place, Anchor can be installed in one of three ways. For development with virtualenv, run:For installing in production, either install a perpared system package, or install globally in the system:In order to run the service, it needs to be started via the `pecan` application server. The only extra parameter is a config file:For development, an additional `--reload` parameter may be used. It will cause the service to reload every time a source file is changed, however it requires installing an additional `watchdog` python module. In the default configuration, Anchor will wait for web requests on port 5000 on local network interface. This can be adjusted in the `config.py` file.In order to test Anchor with the default configuration, the following can be done to create a test CA. The test certificate can be then used to sign the new certificates.That reqest can be submitted using curl (while `pecan serve config.py` is running):This will result in the signed request being created in the `certs` directory.We have provided a Dockerfile that can be used to build a container that will run anchor These instructions expect the reader to have a working Docker install already. Docker should *not* be used to serve Anchor in any production environments. Assuming you are already in the anchor directory, build a container called 'anchor' that runs the anchor service, with any local changes that have been made in the repo: docker build -t anchor . To start the service in the container and serve Anchor on port 8080: docker run -p 8080:5000 anchor The anchor application should be accessible on port 8080. If you are running docker natively on Linux, that will be 8080 on localhost (127.0.0.1). If you are running docker under Microsoft Windows or Apple OSX it will be running in a docker machine. To find the docker machine IP address run:application server (Pecan) and doesn't have all the features you'd normally expect from a http proxy - for example dealing well with deliberately slow connections, or using multiple workers. Anchor can however be run in production using a better frontend.In case a more complex scripted configuration is needed, for example to handle custom headers, rate limiting, or source filtering a complete HTTP proxy like Nginx may be needed. This is however out of scope for Anchor project. You can read more about production deployment inAdditionally, using an AppArmor profile for Anchor is a good idea to prevent exploits relying on one of the native libraries used by Anchor (for example OpenSSL). This can be done with sample profiles which you can find in the `tools/apparmor.anchor_*` files. The used file needs to be reviewed and updated with the right paths depending on the deployment location.One of the main features of Anchor are the validators which make sure that all requests match a given set of rules. They're configured in `config.json` and the sample configuration includes a few of them.* `common_name` ensures CN matches one of names in `allowed_domains` or ranges in `allowed_networks` * `alternative_names` ensures alternative names match one of the names in `allowed_domains` * `alternative_names_ip` ensures alternative names match one of the names in `allowed_domains` or IP ranges in `allowed_networks` * `blacklist_names` ensures CN and alternative names do not contain any of the configured `domains`* `extensions` ensures only `allowed_extensions` are present in the request * `key_usage` ensures only `allowed_usage` is requested for the certificate* `source_cidrs` ensures the request comes from one of the ranges in `cidrs` A configuration entry for a validator might look like one from the sample config:Anchor can use one of the following authentication modules: static, keystone, ldap. Static: Username and password are present in `config.json`. This mode should be used only for development and testing.Keystone: Username is ignored, but password is a token valid in the configured keystone location.LDAP: Username and password are used to bind to an LDAP user in a configured domain. User's groups for the `server_group` filter are retrieved from attribute `memberOf` in search for `(sAMAccountName=username@domain)`. The search is done in the configured base.Anchor allows the use of configurable signing backend. While it provides one implementation (based on cryptography.io and OpenSSL), other implementations may be configured. The resulting certificate is stored locally if the `output_path` is set to any string. This does not depend on the configured backend.documentation for the specific list. The default backend takes the following options:Anchor can modify the submitted CSRs in order to enforce some rules, remove deprecated elements, or just add information. Submitted CSR may be modified or entirely redone. Fixup are loaded from "anchor.fixups" namespace and can take parameters just like validators.For bug reporting and contributing, please check the CONTRIBUTING.md file.

These instructions expect the reader to have a working Docker install already. Docker should *not* be used to serve Anchor in any production environments. We use two Dockerfiles for Anchor. "Dockerfile.anchorbase" is a custom image, built on ubuntu that has lots of libraries and requirements installed in order to quickly test anchor changes and build into CI processes. "Dockerfile.ubuntu" is used to build a complete Anchor stack, based on the latest available ubuntu docker image. Fetch the most recent version of the Dockerfile.ubuntu: git clone -n git://git.openstack.org/openstack/anchor --depth 1 cd anchor git checkout HEAD Dockerfile.ubuntu Build a new Anchor container image using the Dockerfile: docker build -t anchor-dev -f Dockerfile.ubuntu . [Optional] If you have previously built a container using the Dockerfile it will contain a cached version of the Anchor source code. If you require the latest version of anchor, build using the --no-cache option: docker build --no-cache -t anchor-dev -f Dockerfile.ubuntu . Start the service in the container and serve Anchor on port 8080: docker run -p 8080:5000 anchor-dev The anchor application should be accessible on port 8080. If you are running docker natively on Linux, that will be 8080 on localhost (127.0.0.1). If you are running docker under Microsoft Windows or Apple OSX it will be running in a docker machine. To find the docker machine IP address run:Docker development environment ============================== Users who want to quickly test out changes to Anchor or who want to experiment in other ways may find it more convenient to use Dockerfile.anchorbase file. The instructions are very similar to using the ubuntu base as described above. Simply replace "Dockerfile.ubuntu" with "Dockerfile.anchorbase" in the above instructions. application server (Pecan) and doesn't have all the features you'd normally expect from a http proxy - for example dealing well with deliberately slow connections, or using multiple workers. This is however out of scope for Anchor project. This can be done with sample profiles which you can find in the `tools/apparmor.anchor_*` files.
